results.firPara: Riyad Mahrez has given Leicester City a major boost by signing a four-year contract, putting an end to any speculation that he could leave the Premier League champions this summer. The PFA player of the year has followed in the footsteps of Jamie Vardy by agreeing a long-term deal that ties him to the club until 2020 and includes a significant pay rise.
results.secPara: In a welcome development for Leicester before their home game against Arsenal on Saturday, it has also emerged that there is no release clause in Mahrezs new contract, which will make him the clubs second-highest paid player, behind Vardy, who earns around £100,000 a week.
results.webTitle: Riyad Mahrez commits future to Leicester City by signing new contract

results.firPara: West Ham Uniteds André Ayew is facing a significant rehabilitation period as a result of the thigh injury he sustained in the Premier League match at Chelsea on Monday.
results.secPara: The clubs £20m record signing lasted 35 minutes of his debut at Stamford Bridge on Monday before limping off.
results.webTitle: West Ham’s André Ayew out for months after injuring thigh on his debut

results.firPara: Joe Hart is intent on leaving Manchester City before the transfer window closes if a move beneficial to his career is on offer, otherwise the out-of-favour goalkeeper will stay at the club.
results.secPara: While a loan deal to Sevilla, who are interested in the England No1, would provide him with Champions League football, it is understood there is hesitation in the Hart camp as to whether that is only a short-term solution.
results.webTitle: Joe Hart to stay at Manchester City unless he gets move to right club

results.firPara: Jürgen Klopp has said he is astonished by how much people listen to what he has to say. Klopp, whose Liverpool started the season with a thrilling 4-3 win over Arsenal at the Emirates, told the German magazine Stern in an exclusive interview A football manager is listened to in a way that actually makes you wonder about the intelligence of the human race.
results.secPara: I recently met a famous brain surgeon in New York and in his brain, when it comes to intelligence, there are definitely 80% more light bulbs alight than in mine. But what happens? He started to stutter because he is crazy about football and this person from LFC was suddenly standing in front of him.
results.webTitle: Jürgen Klopp: ‘Why do people listen to what football managers have to say?’

results.firPara: In todays Fiver tifo tittle-tattle, free eight anger, and handy transfer caveats
results.secPara: In todays Fiver tifo tittle-tattle, free eight anger, and handy transfer caveats
results.webTitle: The Fiver | An act of outstanding childishness

results.firPara: Sadio Mané is a major doubt for Liverpools trip to Burnley on Saturday following tests on a hurt shoulder, but the forward has given Jürgen Klopp a boost as the injury is a muscle problem rather than the dislocation that had been initially feared.
results.secPara: Mané will be monitored by the clubs medical department and Klopp is expected to address the issue during his weekly media briefing on Thursday at the clubs training ground. The forward has only an outside chance of being fit for the squad for Burnley, it is understood. The 24-year-old had given the manager a major injury scare after he damaged the shoulder during training on Wednesday morning, and was taken to hospital to undergo checks.
results.webTitle: Sadio Mané taken to Liverpool hospital with shoulder injury

results.firPara: At his unveiling as Manchester United manager, José Mourinho was keen to pre-empt any notion that he fails to promote from within a clubs ranks. The Portuguese produced a list of 49 footballers – later increased to 55 – he claimed to have done so with, to prove the point.
results.secPara: Some of these were disingenuous. Arjen Robben was, to offer one  illustration, already a Holland international with 100-plus club  appearances when he joined Mourinho at Chelsea in 2004. Yet the depth of Mourinhos squad – as indicated by the strength of the bench for Sundays 3-1 win at Bournemouth – appears the greatest threat to home-reared footballers being given a chance.
results.webTitle: Where are Louis van Gaal’s Manchester United youngsters now? | Jamie Jackson

results.firPara: When the news broke this month that West Bromwich Albion were to be taken over by the Chinese company Yunyi Guokai, many were left looking for answers. The group which had bought Jeremy Peaces controlling stake was not exactly a household name. There was also an air of mystery around the consortiums front man, Guochuan Lai. The only biographical detail that people could latch on to was that he had made his money in landscape gardening.
results.secPara: Curiously enough this CV entry is something Lai shares with Tony Jiantong Xia. In the late 90s Xia studied landscape design in the prestigious surrounds of Harvard University. Today he is better known as a monosodium glutamate magnate and the new owner of Aston Villa. Alongside the Fosun Group, which recently completed the acquisition of Wolverhampton Wanderers, these investors have conducted what looks like a Chinese takeover of West Midlands football this summer. It may extend further too, with Chinese investors in discussions to take over Hull City.
results.webTitle: How Chinese investment is changing the face of West Midlands football | Paul MacInnes
